contextId.information: This was a customary way of saying "the one who started the fight." AT: "the one who was guilty of starting the fight" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the one who was in the wrong

contextId.information: "Pharaoh hardened his heart." Here "hardened" means that he became stubborn. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This was a customary way of saying "in the presence of someone." AT: "in their presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The words "pass over" were a customary way of saying to not visit or enter. AT: "I will not enter your house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the word "land" refers to Canaan. The expression "born in the land" means a person who is a native Israelite. AT: "those who are Israelites by birth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the people who were born in the land

contextId.information: The words "Call ... to mind" were a customary way of telling someone to remember something. AT: "Remember and celebrate this day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is an idiom. If you have a way of saying this in your language, you can use it here. AT: "has stolen his neighbor's property" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: has put his own hand on his neighbor's property

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means the people were in complete agreement. AT: "together" or "in agreement" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that indicates a person's desire to give an offering. AT: "who wants to give an offering" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: who is motivated by a willing heart

contextId.information: "go in and out from one entrance of the camp to the other entrance" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: go back and forth from entrance to entrance

contextId.information: To know someone by name is to know them well. AT: "I know you well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is part of what Moses was saying to God. AT: "Now If  you are pleased with me" or "Now if you approve of me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Now if I have found favor in your sight

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means that God is pleased with him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:exo:33:12|33:12]]. AT: "I am pleased with you" or "I approve of you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: you have found favor in my sight

contextId.information: Being pleasing to someone is spoken of as finding favor in their sight. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:exo:33:12|33:12]]. AT: "Now If you are pleased with me" or "Now if you approve of me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: If now I have found favor in your sight
